title: Deborah Pilgrim: Missing woman found safe near Sedan
text:
A woman who went missing for three days in bushland has been found safe and well after a local saw an SOS message for help in his driveway.

Deborah Pilgrim, 55, went missing after 6am on Sunday at Sedan, where she had been camping with friends near Pearce Rd, about 1km west of Dry Weather Rd.

There were serious concerns for the Surrey Downs woman health and a search was launched immediately.

Retired police officer Neil Marriott, who owns a bush block in the Sedan area, logged onto his security camera late in the afternoon on Tuesday and noticed “SOS” had been written in the driveway of his property.

He contacted police who searched the property and about midnight, Ms Pilgrim was found on a neighbouring property about 1km away, where she had access to water.

media_camera Police search for Deborah Pilgrim earlier this week. Picture: 9 News

Murray Mallee Superintendent James Blandford said she was found several kilometres outside of their search area.

“We had a defined area, which was over 6 sq km that we were permitted to (search),” he told ABC Radio Adelaide.

“After that, it was really a needle in a hay stack type scenario — we were pretty well coming to the end of what was a viable search area.”

Superintendent Blandford said Ms Pilgrim managed to gain entry to an unoccupied building, where she had shelter and water.

He said all of his officers in the Murray Mallee region were “overjoyed” with the outcome of the search.

“From our perspective, it’s just such a great news story,” he said.

media_camera Police launched a searched for Deborah Pilgrim. Picture: 9 News

Mr Marriott, who lives in Woodside but can check his cameras remotely, said the land was unforgiving.

He said he himself has been lost in the area three times before.

“If you keep your cool and you keep walking, you’ll eventually come to a road.

“It’s very, very dense mallee scrub,” he told ABC Radio Adelaide.

Mr Marriott also said he was in constant contact with police and could see officers searching the property on one of his cameras.

“I’m so pleased she was able to find water, because I feared the worst for her, I really did.”

Mrs Pilgrim appeared to be in good health and was taken to the Angaston Hospital as a precaution.

Police launched a huge search of the area over three days alongside police helicopters, STAR Group, State Tactical Response Group, Murray Mallee police, Mounted Operations and SES volunteers and drones.

Numerous local property owners also joined in the search on foot and on horseback.
description: Deborah Pilgrim, who went missing for three days in bushland, has been found safe and well — all thanks to a message scrawled on a driveway.
